results.title: Pond insects
results.brief_description: The diving water beetle, the mayfly, and the dragonfly represent this group of insects. Their life cycles are portrayed as well as their food habits and struggle for existence.

results.title: Pond animals
results.brief_description: Demonstrates methods of collecting pond animals, both microscopic and macroscopic, and encourages children to study pond life for themselves. A newt, stickleback and wil-i-gig beetle are caught and then in jars to the laboratory to be examined. Other animals seen are the water scorpion, Great Pond Snail, Water Boatmen, Daphnia and others. A drop of pond water is also studied under the microscope.

results.title: Pond (Episode 2)
results.creator_credit: Kenneth Campbell and International Film Bureau
results.brief_description: Examines the interdependent embers of a pond community. Observes life forms above and blow the surface of the water. From he Ecology series, No 2.

results.title: Pompeii: once there was a city
results.creator_credit: Sol Kaplan, Reva Schlesinger and RSK Productions
results.brief_description: Explores the ruins of the ancient city of Pompeii which was buried by volcanic lava in 79 AD. Recreates the everyday lives of its citizens, interspersed with shots of modern day living to suggest contemporary parallels. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Sol Kaplan, Reva Schlesinger and RSK Productions

results.title: Pompeii and Vesuvius
results.brief_description: Shows an actual eruption of Mt Vesuvius and against this background recalls the destruction of the city of Pompeii in 79 AD. The film depicts present-day life in the ruined city of Pompeii and life in the cities and villages around Naples, including folk dancing in Sorrento.
results.description: Shows an actual eruption of Mt Vesuvius and against this background recalls the destruction of the city of Pompeii in 79 AD. The film depicts present-day life in the ruined city of Pompeii and life in the cities and villages around Naples, including folk dancing in Sorrento.

results.title: Polyurethane progress
results.brief_description: A technical film dealing with research, manufacturing processes and the development of outlets for the rigid and flexible foam plastic industry. Illustrates the advanced scientific methods of production, including the moulding of foam car seats by micro-wave units, and the application of rigid foam to wall and other surfaces for insulation purposes.

results.title: Polyester
results.creator_credit: John Waters and New Line Cinema
results.brief_description: A comedy melodrama of the tragic life of Francine Fishpaw (Divine) an obese housewife whose mere existence burdens her so-called loved ones. Unjustly mistreated by her chauvinistic husband Elmer who runs the local porn theatre and money hungry mother, La Rue, she turns to the bottle for love and support. Life is on the downslide for the Fishpaw household with son Dexter, the reputed neighbourhood phantom foot stomper, daughter Lulu, a crazed pregnant disco groupie and the family dog resorting to suicide. Then, in a Cinderella fantasy, Francine meets her Polyester Prince, Todd Tomorrow (Tab Hunter) and blissfully, they fall in love. Has Francine finally found true meaning to life and happiness or will she return to an unsavoury lifestyle with Elmer, Dexter and Lulu? Co-starring Edith Massey, David Samson, Mary Garlington and Ken King.

constellations_other.name: Supplementing cinema
constellations_other.description: A celebration of b-grade cinema's never-ending quest for more, more, more.

results.title: Polychrome phantasy
results.creator_credit: Norman McLaren and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: In this early film Norman McLaren shot crystal formations through a low-power microscope, using polarized light with the lower part of the picture masked off. The film was then rewound and a scene of dancers was filmed. No dialogue or music.

results.title: Polybius
results.creator_credit: James Houston, Joanne Daly, Bold Yin and Channel 4
results.brief_description: A SEGA Mega Drive, Commodore 64, floppy disk drives and hard drives sing in unison. The unusual ensemble (controlled live via MIDI) is given a last curtain call in a nostalgic farewell to forgotten friends.
